video_title: Testing the OM Tech K40 Laser
comment_text:
Just FYI.
Don't run the ground lug to a different ground than what your source of power is using, it is dangerous.

NEC wants an effective ground fault path for ground faults, the Dirt or a rod in the Dirt is not an effective ground fault path. 

An example would be if the metal frame became energized, the dirt has too high of resistance to return the voltage to it's source, in this scenario you would get shocked if you touched it.

A rod in the dirt is only good at discharging static or lightning.

That is why the ground is tied to the neutral in your electrical panel.

If the case becomes energized it will take the path of least resistance back to source through the ground wire which would cause the circuit breaker to become overloaded and open.

That's how the ground wire works. It's an effective ground fault path back to the  source, utility.
Static and lightning discharging back it's source, Earth through the ground rod.

Thanks for the awesome video üëç

video_title: Cheaper and Better?  Atomstack X7 Pro Laser Engraver Review
comment_text: I just bought the X7 pro with extension kit, rotary attachment, extension feet, oversize rollers and pre-purchased the air assist. Basically everything they have for the X7. I've had it for about 2 months and used it a handful of times. It behaved glitchy then it started rebooting 1/3 of the way through any job. It did this running from the computer and from the SD card. Atomstack was pretty cool about replacement of the mainboard. No cost, no shipping fee. The new board should arrive 3/11/22, hopefully that will fix the problem. I'll let you know.

video_title: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?
comment_text: Good and informative review. Thank you! Just one question.. With CO2-lasers the air assist near or on the nossle is for clearing the smoke and fumes, so the beam is unobstructed for a sharper, better result and the focusing lens gets less wear due to particles sticking to it and burning in. In the video you mention air assist, or lack thereof, on diode lasers, but as a lacking safety feature for putting out fires.. Is the use of air assis that different in the two types? In my experience the air assist can promote the opposite, as it fans any fire, adding more oxygen.

video_title: Should You Buy a Glowforge?
comment_text:
I like the concept that Glowforge has, the self contained air assist and cooling is very nice. What I don't like is the software being online. If the company folds you are out of
luck and if the Internet goes down while you are just about to finish off a big job then you are forced to wait.  My son in-law just purchased an OMTech 80Watt laser for about
the same cost of the Glowforge Pro, he can use Lightburn and then have complete control over his designs as well as still being able to run his laser even if Lightburn
goes out of business.

comment_text: The machine looks very cool and I'd love to own one, but man they are expensive... I love the form factor, but the main advantage over an import diode is the air filtration. And a $ 2.600 price difference (the suggested retail price) over a regular diode is way to much. Because of the power and speed of diodes, they will stay in the hobby segment for most people and the price tag is probably to steep for most people to take this machine into consideration. But hey, just my opnion...

comment_text:
Hi Brandon, I have to say, you are the only person that I watch when it comes to laser talk. Though I know nothing of the machines and most of what you speak of is a foreign language to me, I enjoy watching them all the same. With that being said,  I am seriously in need of suggestions because I have absolutely no idea what I need to purchase, especially since I have never laid eyes on a laser/engraver in my life.
Whichever one I purchase will be going inside my craft room in my house. The room is 25 ft long X 13.5 wide so space is not an issue, however, the entrance to my house is only 34‚Äù wide, so it would have to be small enough to go through the entrance.
In no particular order, these are the things that I would love to learn to create‚Ä¶ Jewelry pieces (namely earrings) from wood, leather, and acrylic. I‚Äôd like to be able to cut out the wood to assemble jewelry boxes, shadow boxes, keepsake boxes, small-medium-sized desk organizers, and similar items. I would also like to be able to learn how to make round door signs (at least 15‚Äù), 3D layered designs and other wall decorative items.
I would love to be able to learn how to engrave on leather and acrylic, books, personalize journals, wallets, and a few other items. I am not new to crafting, just new to laser cutting/engraving.
I would greatly appreciate all suggestions that could help me make my final decision as well as any other equipment that could help make things run smoother and of course, the more budget-friendly it is, the better.

video_title: Is this the BEST budget Laser Engraver? Ortur Laser Master Engrave 2 Review
comment_text: I'm looking for a laser engraver to do simple engraving on wood or acrylic pen blanks or the occasional small wood project.  I have a Meterk DK-BL model that is the size of a Jack in the Box but it doesn't have the power to really burn nicely into some woods and I have ruined some projects that I have turned on the lathe due to the object moving as the diode head moves, or the type font not being in real-time what was on the screen.  I might not know what I am doing as well. I am not going into business but rather a simple hobbyist that likes to give nicely engraved gifts to friends.  I would like to stay under $400 if possible.  Thanks in advance.

video_title: What can a $1500 50W Chinese laser actually cut?
comment_text: I have heard a lot of folks saying you have to avoid using the laser over 80% capacity, and a few who say 70% is the cutoff, but you are first one I have heard to say 50%. Considering these Chinese lasers are always 10w under the stated rating, you are ending up with 20w of cutting power. You might as well stick with a diode laser.
